Award.AwardTitle: Development of A Federal CyberForce at Syracuse University: 2010-2014 Scholarship Program

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration: This Federal Cyber Service: Scholarship for Service (SFS) project at Syracuse University (SU) is providing two-year scholarships to eighteen master's students enrolled in programs with an information assurance focus. Three cohorts of six students each are being formed and each student is performing an internship at a federal agency. Students also have the opportunity to conduct research in an information assurance related area. Syracuse university has a strategic partnership with JPMorgan Chase that is developing a new curriculum in Global Enterprise Technologies and that established the JP Morgan Technology Center to provide opportunities for faculty research and student internships that focus on the information assurance challenges encountered in the financial sector. Syracuse University received the National Security Agency and Department of Homeland Security (NSA/DHS) Center of Academic Excellence in Information Assurance Education (CAE/IAE) designation in 2001, and was re-designated as such in 2004 and 2007. Syracuse University also received the NSA/DHS Center of Academic Excellence in Information Assurance Research in 2009. The project includes an assessment and evaluation plan coordinated by an independent evaluator to ensure that the project achieves its objectives. The project's results are being disseminated through conference and professional presentations.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The CyberCorps Scholarship for Service (SFS) program at Syracuse University graduated nineteen students supported by scholarships from this grant to increase and strengthen the cadre of federal information assurance professionals that protect the government's critical information infrastructure.  Our initial target was eighteen students. All of the students supported by the grant completed their master’s degree requirements and the requirements of the Certificate of Advanced Studies in Information Security Management (CAS-ISM) offered by the School of Information Studies.

In addition to their studies, the extra-curricular activities and interdisciplinary interactions among students of the SFS program at Syracuse University helped transfer concepts and knowledge across disciplines such as: information science, engineering, public administration and international relations. These interactions provide for a well prepared human resource that can effectively work in government in the areas of cyber security where technical, policy and political issues must each be considered to solve problems and/or propose new policies.

Of the nineteen graduated students, eleven completed the Master of Science in Information Management, three completed a dual master’s program in Public Administration and International Relations, two earned a master’s in Telecommunications and Network Management, one in Public Administration and one completed a dual master’s program in Public Administration and Telecommunications and Network Management. Additionally, one student earned a Doctor of Professional Studies in Information Management degree from the School of Information Studies.

 In accordance with the objectives of the SFS program, the students that have graduated from the SFS program and obtained government positions have been placed in a diverse set of government agencies and thus are key players in the protection of US government information assets.
